journal-title-group.journal-title: bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology

title-group.article-title: Microbiome-mediated resilience and cross-generational consequences in male Drosophila exposed to combined environmental stressors

contrib-group.aff: Department of Evolutionary Biology and Environmental Studies, https://ror.org/02crff812University of Zurich, Winterthurerstrasse 190, 8057Zurich, Switzerland

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: Environmental stressors like heat extremes and pesticide exposure can significantly threaten insect reproduction, yet the interplay of these stressors and the potential mitigating role of the gut microbiome remain poorly understood, particularly across generations. This study investigated the interactive effects of acute heat stress and sublethal imidacloprid exposure on male Drosophila melanogaster reproductive success and the subsequent fitness of their offspring. We manipulated the gut microbiome of male flies (germ-free or colonized with one or five bacterial species) and subjected them to individual or combined stress. Our findings reveal that combined stress synergistically impairs male fitness traits, an effect partially buffered by higher microbiome diversity. We further demonstrate cross-generational consequences, with paternal stress exposure also impacting offspring fitness. Our results highlight the crucial role of the gut microbiome in mediating resilience to environmental stress and underscore the importance of considering multi-stressor and intergenerational effects in ecological risk assessments.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Coping with the increasing prevalence of anthropogenic stressors is a central challenge for organisms under the ongoing global change (Navarro-Ortega et al., 2015; Piggott, Niyogi, et al., 2015; Piggott, Townsend, et al., 2015; Przeslawski et al., 2015; Segner et al., 2014). Among these stressors, climate change and agricultural pesticides are key drivers of ecosystem-wide biodiversity loss (Beketov et al., 2013; Heino et al., 2009; Stehle & Schulz, 2015), with their interaction posing unique risks. Rising temperatures are projected to intensify pesticide use in agriculture as warmer climates favor pest outbreaks (Deutsch et al., 2018), while simultaneously altering how organisms, particularly ectotherms, respond to chemical exposure (Fournier-Level et al., 2016; Hooper et al., 2013a; Noyes et al., 2009). For ectotherms, which cannot regulate internal temperatures (Deutsch et al., 2008; Paaijmans et al., 2013), warming elevates metabolic rates and feeding activity (and so potentially pesticide uptake), forcing energetic trade-offs between detoxification and essential functions like growth or reproduction (Jutfelt et al., 2021; Pörtner et al., 2017).

While the individual effects of temperature and pesticides are well-documented (Dougherty et al., 2024; Wan et al., 2025), their combined impacts remain poorly resolved. Studies report additive (Arambourou & Stoks, 2015), antagonistic (Meng et al., 2022), or synergistic (Wang et al., 2019) interactions, with synergism being most concerning for non-target species as combined harm exceeds the sum of individual detrimental effects (Folt et al., 1999; Siviter et al., 2021; Verheyen & Stoks, 2019, 2023). Such synergisms may arise through physiological trade-offs, for example if a diversion of resources away from detoxification by heat stress (Dai et al., 2023) is combined with a depletion of antioxidants needed for thermal resilience through pesticide exposure (A. P. N. Silva et al., 2025). Such dual depletion might disproportionately damage gonads and gametes that are particularly prone to oxidative stress due to their high cell proliferation, metabolic rate and generation of reactive oxygen species (Simmons et al. 2018). By eroding reproductive resilience, synergisms threaten to accelerate biodiversity loss in ways single stressors would not (Shahid et al., 2024).

Beyond direct physiological impacts, host-associated microbial communities (microbiomes) are increasingly recognized as mediators for environmental stress tolerance (Feldhaar, 2011; Osborne et al., 2023; Sepulveda & Moeller, 2020b; Shokal et al., 2016). Commensal microbes can enhance host thermal performance (Renoz et al., 2019; Sepulveda & Moeller, 2020a), either as obligate or facultative symbionts (Dunbar et al., 2007; Gruntenko et al., 2017; Montllor et al., 2002; J. A. Russell & Moran, 2006; Zhang et al., 2008). Similarly, a healthy microbiome can bolster insect resistance to insecticides through direct and indirect pathways. For example, symbionts like Citrobacter in the oriental fruit fly Bactrocera dorsalis, or Burkholderia in the bean bug Riptortus pedestris, directly metabolize pesticides using encoded degradation enzymes, whereas others, such as Arsenophonus in Nilaparvata lugens or Lactobacillus in Drosophila melanogaster, can induce the host’s own detoxification gene expression (Cheng et al., 2017; Jones et al., 2015; Kikuchi et al., 2012; Pang et al., 2018). The gut microbiome thus contributes to insect survival and fitness by providing nutrients or mitigating biotic and abiotic stresses (Hector et al., 2022; Perry et al., 2008). However, this protective capacity of the gut microbiota is context-dependent; stressor-induced dysbiosis can impair host fitness, creating feedback loops that may exacerbate vulnerability (Akbar et al., 2022; Evariste et al., 2019; Khosravi & Mazmanian, 2013; Kumar & Kumar, 2019; R. J. Russell et al., 2011; Sepulveda & Moeller, 2020a; Swelam et al., 2022). Despite progress in studying individual stressors, how microbiomes modulate combined effects remains unknown. This gap is critical, as microbiome disruption by one stressor could amplify susceptibility to another, potentially explaining observed synergisms in some species (Karimzadeh et al., 2020; Mao et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2008; Zhang, Cai, et al., 2021).

A parallel knowledge gap concerns stress effects on male reproduction, as much research on environmental stress in invertebrates focuses on acute toxicity or sterility thresholds (de Franca et al., 2017; Desneux et al., 2007; B. S. Walsh, Parratt, Hoffmann, et al., 2019; Zwoinska et al., 2020), overlooking the significant fitness consequences of sublethal exposures. Sublethal effects on female reproductive function are relatively well characterized, but the corresponding consequences for males have only recently come into focus and revealed that male fertility can be far more vulnerable than female fecundity, at least to heat stress (Iossa, 2019; Sales et al., 2018b; Zwoinska et al., 2020). Heat and pesticides have been shown to impair spermatogenesis, sperm DNA integrity, and ejaculate quality more broadly (Aulsebrook, Bertram, Martin, Aulsebrook, Brodin, Evans, Hall, O’Bryan, Pask, & Tyler, 2020; Dougherty et al., 2024; B. S. Walsh, Parratt, Atkinson, et al., 2019). Reductions in ejaculate quality are particularly impactful in promiscuous species, in which the competitive fertilization success depends on the relative ejaculate quantity and quality among rival males (Fitzpatrick & Lüpold, 2014; Parker & Pizzari, 2010; Pizzari & Parker, 2009; Simmons & Fitzpatrick, 2012).

Damage to sperm also has the potential of extending the effects of environmental stress across generations through epigenetic modifications or sperm-borne small RNAs (Bonduriansky et al., 2012; Morgan & Watkins, 2019), with profound consequences for population stability and evolutionary trajectories (Aulsebrook, Bertram, Martin, Aulsebrook, Brodin, Evans, Hall, O’Bryan, Pask, Tyler, et al., 2020; Crean & Immler, 2021). However, although parental exposure to combined thermal and chemical stress has been shown to reduce offspring performance in some species (DeCourten & Brander, 2017; Fathy, 2024), other studies find no clear effects (Massot et al., 2021; Meng et al., 2022) or even reduced offspring vulnerability (Tran et al., 2018), indicating interspecific variation potentially due to differences in stressor intensity (including the thermal sensitivity of pesticides themselves), species-specific acclimation, or compensatory maternal provisioning. Understanding how environmental stressors impact not only directly exposed individuals but also subsequent generations is crucial for predicting long-term ecological consequences and evolutionary adaptation potential.

To address these knowledge gaps, we investigated the interactive effects of acute heat stress and sublethal pesticide exposure on the reproductive fitness of male D. melanogaster, with a focus on microbiome mediation and cross-generational consequences. We combined sublethal acute heat stress (4 hours at 36°C), previously shown to negatively affect testicular function and the fertilizing capacity of sperm (Meena, De Nardo, et al., 2024; Meena, Maggu, et al., 2024), with exposure to imidacloprid, a widely used systemic insecticide targeting nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) in the central nervous system (Ihara et al., 2017). Sublethal imidacloprid impacts have been documented in diverse insects, affecting enzyme activities, biological performance, and gene expression (He et al., 2011; Kang et al., 2018; W. Li et al., 2018), and ultimately impairing fitness (De França et al., 2017; He et al., 2011; Xiao et al., 2016; Zhang, Xu, et al., 2021; Zhou et al., 2017). To isolate the role of the microbiome, we compared males that were germ-free (axenic) with males associated with defined bacterial communities: either mono-association of two common gut bacteria (Acetobacter tropicalis or Lactobacillus brevis) or a more complex, yet defined, five-species consortium combining Acetobacter and Lactobacillus species that are commonly found in Drosophila (Broderick & Lemaitre, 2012; Gould et al., 2018; Newell & Douglas, 2014; Ridley et al., 2013). This gnotobiotic approach (i.e., using defined microbiotas) enabled precise assessment of microbial contributions to stress tolerance. Furthermore, we assessed the cross-generational consequences of paternal stress exposure by examining offspring fitness, explicitly testing whether the father’s microbiome status influences these cross-generational effects. Our design minimized bacterial transmission to offspring, focusing the analysis on direct paternal effects related to parental condition (Marshall et al., 2010; Moore et al., 2019; Mousseau et al., 2009).

Based on the evidence outlined above, we tested the following five predictions: (1) Combined sublethal exposure to heat stress and imidacloprid will synergistically reduce male reproductive fitness more than the individual effects of each stressor. (2) The presence of gut microbes will partially mitigate the negative impacts of individual and combined stressors on male reproductive fitness compared to germ-free males. (3) Different bacterial compositions (mono-associations vs. defined complex community) will vary in their protective capacity, with the more complex community offering greater resilience than either mono-association. (4) Paternal exposure to individual and combined stressors will negatively impact offspring fitness (cross-generational effects), with synergistic interactions between stressors potentially amplifying this fitness loss. (5) The composition of the paternal microbiome will influence the magnitude of these cross-generational effects.

sec.title: Experimental populations
sec.p: Throughout this study, we used an outbred D. melanogaster population (LHm wild-type strain), maintained under constant conditions of 25°C, 60% humidity, and a 12h:12h light:dark cycle. First, we generated axenic (germ-free) focal flies by collecting eggs (within six hours of oviposition) from four large population containers supplied with Petri dishes containing grape-juice agar medium (300 mL water, 670 mL grape juice, 22g agar, 20g sugar, 19g yeast, 20 mL nipagin per litre) supplemented with a smear of yeast paste. Eggs were washed off the plates into a strainer, pooled, and dechorionated by immersion in 3.5% bleach for 2 minutes, followed by a rinse in 70% ethanol and three rinses in sterile water.

Next, eggs were aseptically transferred to sterile glass vials containing autoclaved standard fly food (75g glucose, 100g fresh yeast, 55g corn, 10g flour, and 15mL nipagin antimicrobial agent per litre food media) supplemented with antibiotics [a cocktail of Ampicillin (50mg/mL), Kanamycin (50mg/mL), Erythromycin (10mg/mL), Tetracycline (10 mg/mL)]. Vials were then sealed with sterile plugs and incubated under standard laboratory conditions until adult eclosion. All steps of vial preparation were conducted in a laminar flow chamber to avoid contamination.

Upon eclosion, axenic status was confirmed using two methods on a subsample of flies. First, homogenated flies were plated on Lysogeny Broth (LB) and de Man, Rogosa and Sharpe (MRS) agar plates, incubated, and checked for bacterial colony growth. Second, genomic DNA was extracted from pools of 3-5 putatively germ-free and conventional flies (positive control), respectively, using Quick-DNA midiprep plus kit following the instructions provided by the manufacturer. Universal primers (27F and 1492R) were used as forward and reverse primer, respectively. To prepare the PCR master mix, 10μL of nuclease-free water, 0.5μL of forward and reverse primer, 1μL of template DNA and 13μL Taq green master mix were mixed in a sterile eppendorf tube. PCR conditions were: initial denaturation at 95°C for 90s, followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 95°C for 30s, annealing at 55°C for 30s and extension at 72°C for 90s, and final extension at 72°C for 5 minutes). PCR products were visualized on a 1% agarose gel under ultraviolet light to confirm the absence of bacterial DNA amplification in axenic samples and its presence in controls.

sec.title: Bacterial cultures and gnotobiotic associations
sec.p: Axenic males were associated with defined compositions of microbial species, all originally isolated from the gut of wild-type flies (Obadia et al., 2017): Acetobacter tropicalis (At), and Lactobacillus brevis (Lb) for mono-associations based on their contrasting effects on male reproductive investments in our previous studies (Maggu et al. in prep.). For comparison, we also included axenic males and males inoculated with a defined five-species community consisting of common and abundant Drosophila gut bacteria (A. tropicalis, A. orientalis, A. pasteurianus, L. plantarum, L. brevis), resulting in four distinct microbial treatments.

Bacterial strains were cultured overnight in an incubator at 30°C: Acetobacter in MRS + mannitol medium with shaking, and Lactobacillus in MRS broth under stationary conditions. The following morning, cultures were checked for growth before measuring their optical densities (OD) at 600 nm and centrifuging at 7000 rpm for 5 minutes. Bacterial pellets were then resuspended in sterile phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) to a final concentration of 108 cells/mL, following established protocols (Koyle et al., 2016; Newell & Douglas, 2014).

To inoculate vials, 50µL of bacterial suspension (approx. 5×106 CFUs) was added to sterile food vials, with equal representation of bacterial strains in the 5-species consortia. This bacterial density is comparable to previous reports for conventionally reared flies (Gould et al., 2018; Newell & Douglas, 2014). Inoculated food vials were then allowed to air-dry in a laminar flow cell before introducing ten 1-day-old axenic males to each to generate gnotobiotic flies. Males were transferred to freshly inoculated vials with the same bacterial treatment every 48h for a total of four days to ensure stable colonization. Successful colonization with the intended bacteria was confirmed by plating homogenates of males from each treatment and checking for characteristic colony morphologies (see Bacterial abundance of males).

sec.title: Stress treatments
sec.p: Following the 4-day colonization period, males were transferred to vials containing sterile food and exposed to pesticide and heat stress in a fully factorial design. Specifically, half of the males from each microbial group were subjected to food supplemented with imidacloprid, whilst the remaining half were maintained on uncontaminated standard food. We used a concentration of 1 ppm (parts per million) of imidacloprid as concentrations of 0.04 to 20 ppm have been used effectively in studies on larval or adult D. melanogaster, depending on the exposure regime (Charpentier et al., 2014a; Frantzios et al., 2008; Martelli et al., 2020). These concentrations are low enough to avoid immediate lethality but sufficient to induce sublethal effects on behavior, reproduction, and physiology. Males were exposed to imidacloprid for an acute window of 18 h, following an additional thermal treatment of 4-hour in a hot water bath. To this end, half of the males from each microbiome and pesticide treatment were subjected to acute heat stress by transferring them to vials containing only sterile 1% agar (to prevent dehydration) and placing these vials in a water at 36°C for 4 hours. The remaining males (thermal controls) were treated identically but at benign 24.5°C. All males were then allowed to recover overnight in standard food vials under standard laboratory conditions.

sec.title: Hatching success and fertility
sec.p: To quantify the fitness consequences of heat and pesticide exposure and their potential mitigation by the microbiome on the morning after the stress treatments, experimental males were individually mated to standard females of the same population. All females had been collected as virgins (within 7 hours of eclosion) and reared under axenic conditions along with the experimental males to minimize confounding contributions of female microbes to the measured outcomes. After mating ended, females were allowed to lay eggs for 24 h, and another 30 h later (allowing time for embryonic development), oviposition vials were frozen for later quantification of the proportion of eggs hatching as a proxy of fertilization success, and the total number of larvae estimating male-mediated fecundity. This assay was performed in two blocks, each with 25 males per treatment combination, totaling 800 experimental males (4 bacterial treatments × 2 pesticide treatments × 2 temperature treatments × 2 blocks × 25 males).

sec.title: Sperm competitiveness
sec.p: To assess male sperm competitiveness, the above experimental design was repeated, but this time using standard females that had mated once with standard competitor males two days before the focal mating. These standard competitors were of the same strain but genetically modified to ubiquitously express green fluorescent protein (GFP), permitting paternity assignment against the focal wild-type males (Lüpold et al., 2012, 2020). Pairs were monitored for remating for up to 8 h. Remated females were then isolated in fresh vials for oviposition, while pairs not mating were separated and given another 8-hour mating opportunity on the following day. Females still not remating were excluded. Offspring paternity (focal vs. competitor) was assessed via GFP fluorescence to calculate P2 as the proportion of offspring sired by the second (focal) male. The treatment design of this assay was identical to the non-competitive experiment above, but this time with 30 trials per treatment combination in each of the two experimental blocks (i.e., 960 trials in total).

sec.title: Bacterial abundance of males
sec.p: To investigate the impact of stress treatments on the bacterial load, colony forming units (CFUs) were compared between ten random males from each experimental treatment, surface-sterilized with 70% ethanol, and individually homogenized in 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes containing sterile PBS using a pestle. Homogenates were serially diluted to different dilutions at a final volume of 100 μL, then plated on MRS media for quantification of CFUs at appropriate dilutions (approx. 100 CFUs/plate). For the control groups with both Acetobacter and Lactobacillus species, MRS agar was supplemented with 10 μg/mL ampicillin to avoid the growth of Lactobacillus, whilst replicate plates were incubated in a CO2 atmosphere to exclude the growth of Acetobacter. The presence of only target bacterial species on plates was confirmed based on colony morphologies, with A. tropicalis producing small tan-brown colonies and L. brevis producing small yellowish colonies. CFUs per fly were calculated as: CFU = C × D/P × V, where C = number of colonies counted, D = dilution, P = volume plated, V = volume of fly homogenate (Koyle et al., 2016). For control males, with all the five bacterial species, bacterial colonies were identified by their morphology and total CFUs per fly was obtained by adding CFUs from all the five bacterial species.

sec.title: Cross-generational effects
sec.p: To assess cross-generational impacts of paternal (F0) stress exposure, we quantified hatching success and fecundity in both male and female offspring (F1) of our experimental males. Within each experimental block, up to 20 freshly hatched larvae from each of ten randomly selected vials per parental treatment combination (i.e., 16 combinations) were transferred to rearing vials containing sterilized standard fly food. This immediate transfer minimized the potential acquisition of parental microbes via consumption of the egg chorion or contaminated food. These larvae developed under standard laboratory conditions.

Upon eclosion, 4-5 virgin F1 male and female offspring were collected from each rearing vial, separated by sex. At 2-3 days of age, three males and three females from each lineage were individually mated with a virgin standard fly of the opposite sex reared under axenic conditions (to avoid potential confounding effects of their microbiota). Following copulation, hatching success and fecundity were measured for these F1 flies as in their parents (see above). These offspring themselves were not subjected to any experimental treatment, thus assessing solely the cross-generational effects. This experiment was carried out in two independent blocks of 480 offspring per sex from 160 F0 males (i.e. total of 1,920 mating trials).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All statistical analyses were performed in R version 4.4.0 (R core team, 2024), using generalized linear mixed-effects models (GLMMs) and generalized linear models (GLMs) to assess the male responses to heat stress and/or pesticide exposure under different microbiome conditions. Each model included microbiome composition (4-level factor) along with the binary thermal and pesticide treatments with all two- and three-way interactions as fixed effects, and experimental block as a fixed or random effect. Pairwise comparisons were performed using the emmeans package (Searle et al., 1980) (Estimated Marginal Means) to assess the significance of differences between levels of each factor.

Hatching success (i.e., proportion of all eggs that hatched) was analyzed in a quasibinomial GLMM (as the binomial distribution resulted in under-dispersion), with block as a fixed effect. Male-mediated female fecundity (i.e., total number of eggs laid) was modeled using a truncated Poisson model with a zero-inflation component as implemented in the package glmmTMB (Brooks et al., 2017), also including block as a fixed effect. Finally, for sperm competitiveness (P2), we fitted a GLMM (glmmTMB) with a Tweedie distribution and a log link function to account for skewness and under-dispersion in the data. Experimental block and male ID were included as random effects.

The impact of the different experimental treatments was also analyzed for the total bacterial abundances (CFUs) and, separately, for compositional shifts in the five-species consortia. For the former, we used a linear mixed-effects model with block as a random effect. For microbiome community composition in the five-species consortium, we quantified the species-specific abundances per sample, then applied a Hellinger transformation to these count data and computed Bray-Curtis distances using the vegdist function in the package vegan (Oksanen et al., 2023). We assessed treatment effects (temperature, pesticide, and their interaction) in a permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) using adonis2 in the same package. To visualize compositional shifts, we further ran non-metric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) (metaMDS) on the Bray-Curtis dissimilarities and fitted species vectors onto the NMDS ordination with envfit, which indicates the direction and strength of each species-specific association with the ordination space. We also compared the relative abundances at the genus level, using a binomial GLMM with block as a random effect and accounting for overdispersion by including an additional observation-level random effect.

Finally, the effects of paternal (F0) treatments on offspring (F1) fitness were quantified separately for male and female progeny using GLMMs. Each model included F0 treatments and their interactions as fixed effects (as above), with experimental block and sire ID as random effects. GLMMs for hatching success included a zero-inflation component (for females), whilst those for hatching success used a Tweedie distribution to account for under-dispersion.
We investigated the performance of all models using the DHARMa package (Florian, 2016).

sec.title: Hatching success
sec.p: To assess the combined effects of heat stress, pesticide exposure, and microbiome composition on male reproductive function, we first investigated fertilization success, estimated as the proportion of eggs hatched out of all eggs laid by females. A GLM revealed a significant three-way interaction between microbiome composition, temperature, and pesticide presence (N = 650, χ2 = 16.07, df = 3, p = 0.0011; Fig. 1, Supplementary Tables S1, S2), highlighting that the combined effects of these environmental stressors depended on the microbial composition of the focal males. Overall, males associated with all five bacterial strains exhibited the highest hatching success, followed by At- and Lb-associated males, with axenic males being most severely affected. These general patterns were also confirmed by the significant two-way interactions of temperature × microbiome (χ2 = 12.13, df = 3, p = 0.007) and temperature × pesticide (χ2 = 43.32, df = 1, p < 0.0001), as well as by all main effects (all χ2 ≥ 520.76, df ≥ 3, p ≤ 0.001; Supplementary Tables S1, S2).

sec.title: Male-mediated fecundity
sec.p: Next, we investigated male-mediated fecundity, quantified as the total number of larvae produced per female. In contrast to hatching success, the three-way interaction was not significant (χ2 = 0.319, df = 3, p = 0.956; Supplementary Table S3, S4) for this metric and was removed from the final model. The simplified model revealed significant two-way interactions between microbiome and temperature (N = 650, χ2 = 7.85, df = 3, p = 0.049) and between temperature and pesticide (χ2 = 5.41, df = 1, p = 0.020; Supplementary Tables S3, S4). All main effects were again significant (all χ2 ≥ 5.41, p ≤ 0.001). The relative differences in fecundity between males with different microbiome statuses largely mirrored the patterns observed for hatching success (Fig. 2).

sec.title: Sperm competitiveness
sec.p: Since sperm competitive ability is a crucial determinant of male reproductive fitness in polygamous species and there are reports of adverse effects of increased temperatures and pesticide exposure on sperm quality and function (Chirault et al., 2015; Meena, De Nardo, et al., 2024; D. R. Moreira et al., 2022; S. Moreira et al., 2021; Roy et al., 2017; Sales et al., 2018a, 2024), we evaluated the combined effects of our treatments on the proportion of progeny sired by focal males relative to their standard competitors (i.e., P2). Although the three-way interaction was not statistically significant (N = 331, χ2 = 1.003, df = 3, p = 0.800), all two-way interactions were (Supplementary Tables S5, S6): temperature × microbiome (χ2 = 22.92, df = 3, p < 0.001), microbiome × pesticide (χ2 = 11.89, df = 3, p < 0.001), and temperature × pesticide (χ2 = 27.33, df = 1, p < 0.001). Similarly, all main effects on P2 were significant (all χ2 ≥ 472.33, p ≤ 0.001). These results indicate strong interdependent effects of the treatments on sperm competitiveness, with the relative performance across different microbiome groups again showing similar patterns to those observed for hatching success and fecundity (Fig. 3).

sec.title: Bacterial abundance in males in response to heat stress and pesticide exposure
sec.p: We also analyzed the effect of heat stress and pesticide exposure and their interactions on the growth and viability of commensal bacteria inside their host under the different stress treatments by quantifying their colony forming units in homogenates of focal males immediately after mating. For total CFU counts, we found a significant three-way interaction (χ2 = 5.06, df = 2, p = 0.008; Supplementary Tables S7, S8), suggesting that the bacterial strains differed in their accumulation patterns in adult flies depending on the combined effects of environmental stress factors. Additionally, we documented significant two-way interactions and main effects of all three factors (all χ2 ≥ 42.31, p ≤ 0.001), except for the two-way interaction between the two stressors (χ2 = 2.36, df = 2, p = 0.127). Among these and relative to the control microbiome, higher temperature had a stronger negative effect on the total number of CFUs than pesticide exposure (Fig. 4; Supplementary Tables S7, S8).

A PERMANOVA controlling for block effects (F1,35 = 0.20, p = 0.874, Supplementary Table S9) revealed that temperature was also the dominant driver of variation in the relative abundances of the five bacterial species constituting the consortium, explaining 26.3% of the variation in community composition (F1,35 = 13.88, p = 0.0001; Supplementary Table S9). In contrast, the main effect of pesticide was not statistically significant (2.2% of variation, F1,35 = 1.16, p = 0.314), and the temperature × pesticide interaction showed a marginal effect (4.8% of variation, F1,35 = 2.55, p = 0.068). NMDS based on Bray-Curtis dissimilarities provided a visual representation of community shifts across treatments. The NMDS ordination (Fig. 5) indicated that the first axis (NMDS1) predominantly tracked the temperature gradient, while the second axis (NMDS2) aligned more, but only weakly, with pesticide exposure. Overlaying species vectors revealed notable differences in species associations (all R2 ≥ 0.54, p ≤ 0.0001), in that both Lactobacillus species showed positive (≥ 0.68), and all Acetobacter exhibited negative (≤ -0.38), loadings on NMDS1 (Supplementary Table S10), suggesting an increase in the relative abundance of Acetobacter in the high-temperature regimes. By contrast, loadings on NMDS2 were negative for A. tropicalis (-0.92) and L. brevis (-0.44) but positive for all remaining species (≥ 0.56). This axis tended to be biased toward negative values in the absence of imidacloprid, but more ambiguous in its presence.

Finally, in a binomial GLMM focusing only on the relative abundances of acetic acid versus lactic acid bacteria, where the three Acetobacter species should theoretically constitute 60% of the total CFUs among the five species, temperature and pesticide presence interacted significantly (N = 40, z = 2.15, p = 0.032). Specifically, the relative representation of Acetobacter was increased to around 66% under heat stress (z = 2.84, p = 0.013), whereas pesticide exposure reduced its representation (z = -2.32, p = 0.021), although only at the benign temperature (Fig. 6).

sec.title: Cross-generational effects on offspring fitness
sec.p: Finally, we investigated whether the effects of paternal stress exposure carried over to the next generation by measuring the hatching success and fecundity of F1 offspring produced by F0 males from each treatment group.

We found a significant interactive effect between paternal temperature and pesticide treatments on the hatching success of both male (N = 726, χ2 = 19.39, df = 1, p < 0.001; Supplementary Tables S11,12) and female offspring (N = 750, χ2 = 10.084, df = 1, p < 0.001; Supplementary Tables S13,14). This indicates that the combined effects of heat and pesticide stress experienced by fathers carried over to the next generation. However, the composition of the paternal gut microbiome did not significantly influence offspring hatching success (χ2 ≤ 4.76, df = 3, p ≥ 0.19). The interactive effect of paternal temperature and pesticide exposure was not significant for the fecundity induced by sons (χ2 = 0.36, df = 1, p = 0.55; Supplementary Tables S15,16). In contrast, the interaction between these two paternal stressors showed significant effect on fecundity of F1 daughters (N = 750, χ2 = 3.990, df = 1, p = 0.006; Supplementary Tables S17,18). There was also a non-significant trend for a main effect of paternal microbiome composition on offspring fecundity in daughters (χ2 = 7.26, df = 3, p = 0.06; Supplementary Tables S17,18).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We investigated the role of the gut microbiome in modulating male reproductive success in D. melanogaster under individual and combined exposure to acute heat stress and the pesticide imidacloprid. Our results confirm and extend previous work that demonstrated the detrimental effects of sublethal temperatures (Canal Domenech & Fricke, 2022; David et al., 2005; Fasolo & Krebs, 2004; Gandara & Drummond-Barbosa, 2022, 2023; Meena, De Nardo, et al., 2024; Pilakouta & Baillet, 2022; Sales et al., 2024; B. S. Walsh, Parratt, Atkinson, et al., 2019) or imidacloprid (Charpentier et al., 2014b; Xiao et al., 2016; Zhang, Xu, et al., 2021; Zhou et al., 2017) on different reproductive functions in diverse organisms. However, our study adds a crucial layer of complexity by revealing both the combined effects of these stressors and the critical role of the microbiome in mediating the response of stressed males. Specifically, our findings highlight the importance of the gut microbiome in mitigating fitness losses under stress. Acetobacter generally offered stronger protection than Lactobacillus, while the complex microbial community provided the highest benefits. Furthermore, we show that paternal stress exposure imposes fitness costs on the next generation, although these cross-generational effects were not significantly mediated by the paternal microbiome in our experimental design aimed at minimizing direct microbial transmission.

sec.title: Interactive effects of combined stressors on male reproduction
sec.p: Our study revealed that initial exposure to imidacloprid followed by heat shock reduced male reproductive functions more than either stressor alone. This observation aligns with previous studies indicating complex, often order-dependent interactions between thermal stress and pesticide toxicity (Ahmed et al., 2023; Deng et al., 2016; Meng et al., 2022; Ricupero et al., 2020; Y.-C. Wang, Chang, Bai, Zhang, Iqbal, Lu, Gong, et al., 2021). For example, heat stress has been shown to increase the tolerance to subsequent insecticide exposure in diverse insect pests, such as the serpentine leaf miner, Liriomyza trifoli (Y.-C. Wang, Chang, Bai, Zhang, Iqbal, Lu, Hu, et al., 2021a); diamond back moth, Plutella xylostella (Gu et al., 2010); wheat aphid, Sitobion avenae (Cao et al., 2021), or brown planthopper, Nilaparvata lugens (Ge et al., 2013). The order of stress treatments, however, has had an opposing effect in other insects (Delnat et al., 2019; Y.-C. Wang, Chang, Bai, Zhang, Iqbal, Lu, Gong, et al., 2021). In L. trifoli, for example, where both orders in stress exposure were examined, elevated temperatures improved survival under exposure to the insecticide abamectin, whereas the reverse stress sequence reduced survival (Y.-C. Wang, Chang, Bai, Zhang, Iqbal, Lu, Gong, et al., 2021), indicating the importance of stress sequence in cross-protection between multiple stressors.

Pre-exposure to insecticides can also decrease heat stress tolerance, suggesting that warmer temperatures may exacerbate insecticide toxicity depending on the exposure sequence. Increased imidacloprid toxicity at higher temperatures has been documented in mayflies (Macaulay et al., 2020), earthworms Eisenia andrei and collembolans Folsomia candida (Bandeira et al., 2020). In the terrestrial ectotherm Hypogastrura viatica, sublethal concentrations of imidacloprid became lethal on increasing the temperatures resulting in reduced survival, growth and egg production (A. S. J. Silva et al., 2023). Our study corroborates these findings, with decreased male reproductive success when pesticide exposure preceded heat stress. These multi-stressor studies highlight the complex interplay between temperature and toxicity, which can be positive or negative depending on the mode of action of the insecticide, the route of exposure, and the insect species. Therefore, the sequence of exposure must be carefully considered when evaluating combined stressor effects on insect performance.

The mechanisms underlying these sequence-dependent interactions likely involve intricate physiological adjustments. For example, exposure to one stressor might compromise pathways needed to cope with the subsequent stressor (lack of cross-tolerance) or trigger shared signaling pathways that amplify susceptibility (negative cross-talk). Resource allocation trade-offs are also probable (Sokolova, 2013), in that coping with pesticide toxicity may deplete energy reserves or specific molecules (e.g., antioxidants, chaperones) needed to subsequently mount an effective heat stress response. Generally, stressful environments may alter resource allocation among essential processes like growth, reproduction, or immune defense to optimize fitness outcomes (Kooijman, 2000). As such, elevated temperature may increase somatic maintenance costs (Verberk et al., 2016), potentially reducing resources available for defense and repair (Hallman & Brooks, 2015).

While the precise mechanisms underlying increased toxicity at high temperatures remain unclear, they may overlap with those explaining the increased toxicity of organophosphate pesticides at higher mean temperatures (Noyes et al., 2009; Noyes & Lema, 2015a). Increased temperatures can enhance the activity of detoxification enzymes like cytochrome P450s (Y.-C. Wang, Chang, Bai, Zhang, Iqbal, Lu, Hu, et al., 2021b), accelerating the breakdown of pesticides like pyrethroids (Ahmad, 2007). Increased uptake of chemicals at higher temperatures (Holmstrup et al., 2010), possibly due to higher basal metabolism (Hooper et al., 2013b), increased membrane permeability (Noyes & Lema, 2015b), and or smaller body size (Gardner et al., 2011) has also been observed. Stressful conditions can promote the accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) due to reduced respiration and increased water loss, thereby negatively affecting development and reproduction (Dampc et al., 2021). For example, low doses of imidacloprid have been shown to cause ROS formation and metabolic impairment in D. melanogaster (Martelli et al., 2020). Both pesticide tolerance (Bagchi et al., 1996) and heat stress (Neven, 2000) are also associated with overexpression of heat-shock proteins like Hsp70 and Hsp90. In the honeybee, for example, these two Hsps followed similar expression patterns in response to both thermal stress and imidacloprid exposure (Manzi et al., 2020). This thermal stress-mediated chaperone activation could also be a relevant mechanism in D. melanogaster males exposed to imidacloprid, for cellular protection against combined stressors. If so, the observed fitness loss following heat and pesticide stress might at least in part be attributable to the costs associated with enhanced Hsp expression (Hoekstra et al., 2013; S. Li et al., 2015), which may become overwhelming under combined stress.

sec.title: Microbiome as a modulator of stress resilience
sec.p: A key finding of our study was the significant role of the gut microbiome in mitigating the detrimental reproductive consequences of heat and pesticide stress. Across all measured fitness components (hatching success, fecundity, sperm competitiveness), axenic males consistently performed worse than males colonized with bacteria, highlighting the baseline importance of the microbiome for reproductive function even under benign conditions, and its crucial role under stress. The reduced fitness of axenic males under combined stress suggests an impaired ability to metabolize and excrete imidacloprid, potentially leading to higher internal toxin loads and thus increased vulnerability to subsequent heat stress.

Interestingly, the degree of protection conferred depended on the microbial composition. While both Lactobacillus brevis and Acetobacter tropicalis mono-associations offered benefits over the axenic state, the 5-species community consistently provided the greatest resilience, resulting in the highest reproductive fitness across most conditions. This underscores the potential importance of microbial diversity and inter-species interactions for robust host function (Coyte et al., 2015; Freilich et al., 2011; Levy & Borenstein, 2013; Magnúsdóttir et al., 2017; Noecker et al., 2019; Zelezniak et al., 2015). Mono-associations might lack the metabolic versatility or synergistic cross-feeding capabilities present in more complex consortia, limiting their ability to buffer the host against multiple stressors.

Our results partially contrast with Daisley et al. (2017), who reported that Lactobacillus plantarum (Lp39) supplementation rescued D. melanogaster from harmful imidacloprid effects, accompanied by increased Acetobacter and Lactobacillus abundance. We did not observe such a strong rescue with L. brevis, nor an increased abundance of either bacterial genus. This discrepancy could stem from strain-specific functions, similar to opposing effects on chlorpyrifos (CP) toxicity between L. plantarum ISO and Lactobacillus ATCC in D. melanogaster (Daisley et al., 2017). Alternatively, differences in experimental protocols could also contribute to the contrasting results between our and Daisley’s studies (e.g., our acute 18h imidacloprid exposure versus Daisley et al.’s (2017) continued exposure).

We also observed shifts in the relative abundance of Acetobacter and Lactobacillus within the host, aligning with studies showing heat-induced microbiome disruptions (Jaramillo & Castañeda, 2021; Kokou et al., 2018; Moghadam et al., 2018a). Apparently, in mono-associations, Lactobacillus was more abundant and less affected by treatments than Acetobacter, however, the latter seemed to be overrepresented in 5-species consortium relative to the expected proportion. Generally, we found a higher proportional representation of Acetobacter following acute heat stress, consistent with prior work reporting increased Acetobacter (but fewer Leuconostoc bacteria) in heat- compared to cold-acclimated flies (Moghadam et al., 2018b). While this previous study exposed individuals to thermal treatments throughout development, our findings demonstrate that such compositional shifts can occur rapidly (within hours).

The mechanisms by which the microbiome enhances stress tolerance likely involve multiple pathways. Beyond direct detoxification (Cheng et al., 2017; Jones et al., 2015; Kikuchi et al., 2012; Pang et al., 2018), gut microbes significantly impact host nutrition and metabolism (Douglas, 2009; Ridley et al., 2012), which are intrinsically linked to thermal tolerance in ectotherms (Henry et al., 2020; Moeller et al., 2020; Moghadam et al., 2018a; Semsar-Kazerouni et al., 2020). It has been shown in D. melanogaster that the gut microbiota influences nutrient allocation, including levels of the thermo-protectant trehalose (Overgaard et al., 2007; Ridley et al., 2012; Schwasinger-Schmidt et al., 2012). They can also modulate host immune responses and potentially Hsp expression in the gut epithelium (Arnal & Lalles, 2016; Liu et al., 2014). Given the critical role of Hsps in mitigating thermal stress in D. melanogaster (Calabria et al., 2012; Sørensen et al., 2003), and their rapid induction after heat exposure (Hoekstra et al., 2013), the microbiota may enhance heat tolerance in conventional and mono-associated flies by promoting higher Hsp levels. Disrupting the microbiome can alter these processes. For instance, heat-induced reductions in the abundance of the bacterial symbiont Buchnera aphidicola in pea aphids lowered heat resistance, with fitness costs for the host due to a deficiency of Buchnera-derived essential amino acids (Dunbar et al., 2007). Similarly, temperature-driven microbiome shifts have been reported in mice (Chevalier et al., 2015) and Nilaparvata lugens, with the disrupted microbiome assembly in the latter case being harmful by increasing imidacloprid susceptibility (Zhang, Cai, et al., 2021).

sec.title: Cross-generational impacts of parental stress
sec.p: We found clear evidence for cross-generational fitness costs of paternal stress exposure, with reduced hatching success and fecundity in offspring of fathers exposed to heat and/or pesticide stress. Cross-generational effects can either increase (Pölkki et al., 2012; Schultz et al., 2016) or decrease (Brausch & Salice, 2011; Kim et al., 2014; Reátegui-Zirena et al., 2017) offspring vulnerability to stressors compared to the parental generation. Our results are consistent with studies reporting detrimental cross- or transgenerational effects of paternal heat stress (Ferrer et al., 2013; Guillaume et al., 2016; Shama et al., 2014; M. R. Walsh et al., 2014) or toxicant exposure (Bhandari et al., 2015; Kimberly & Salice, 2015; Schultz et al., 2016; Yu & Liao, 2016), possibly through epigenetic processes (Schultz et al., 2016). The observed synergism between paternal heat and pesticide exposure in offspring fitness underscores the potential for long-lasting consequences of multi-stressor events.

Offspring from stressed fathers exhibited reduced fecundity and hatching success and did not demonstrate increased tolerance to the same stressors, indicating that paternal exposure to warming and/or pesticide does not buffer against these environmental stressors. These results contrast with a growing number of studies suggesting that cross-generational effects can buffer offspring against rapid environmental change (Donelson et al., 2018; Munday, 2014), with parental heat exposure even being considered as a strategy to enhance species resilience (Chakravarti et al., 2017). Instead, our findings align with previous work revealing negative effects of heat and pesticide stress on offspring survival (Tran et al., 2018) and support the view that cross-generational effects of stress are often non-adaptive or costly for offspring (Uller et al., 2013), highlighting the potential for cumulative fitness declines across generations in populations facing recurrent multi-stressor events.

Intriguingly, the paternal microbiome did not significantly mediate these cross-generational effects in our study. This could be attributable to our experimental design, which deliberately minimized vertical transmission or environmental acquisition of microbes by using axenic mothers and transferring these and their offspring to sterile food vials immediately after mating or hatching, respectively. This allowed us to isolate direct paternal effects (potentially epigenetic or related to gamete quality) based on the sire’s microbial status. However, we cannot rule out a role for the paternal microbiome if transmission occurs naturally (e.g., during copulation) (Guilhot et al., 2025), which then triggers differential maternal effects or microbial deposition on the chorion of eggs (direct paternal transmission of microbes to their offspring seems rather unlikely as males have little control over female oviposition). Future studies explicitly allowing or manipulating vertical transmission would be needed to explore this.

sec.title: Conclusions and broader implications
sec.p: Our study demonstrates that acute heat stress and sublethal exposure to pesticides (e.g., imidacloprid) interact, often synergistically, to negatively impact male reproductive fitness in D. melanogaster, with consequences extending to offspring viability and fecundity. Crucially, we show that the gut microbiome is a key determinant of resilience, offering significant protection against these stressors, with benefits enhanced by microbial complexity. However, the microbiome itself is vulnerable to disruption by these same stressors.

Our findings underscore the critical need to consider multi-stressor interactions and the role of host-associated microbes when assessing the ecological risks posed by climate change and agrochemical use. Predicting population responses requires moving beyond single-stressor studies to understand these complex interdependencies. The observed negative cross-generational effects further suggest that transient stress events could have prolonged demographic consequences. From a conservation perspective, these results highlight the potential vulnerability of insect populations, particularly those with depleted or altered microbiomes, to the combined pressures of warming climates and continued pesticide application. Future research should explore these interactions across diverse species, environments, and stressor combinations to improve ecological forecasting and develop strategies for mitigating biodiversity loss in the Anthropocene.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We thank T. Ratz and G. Raina for valuable comments on our manuscript. This project was funded by the Swiss National Science Foundation (grant PP00P3_202662 to S.L.) and a University of Zurich Postdoctoral Fellowship (to K.M.).

caption.p: Proportion of eggs fertilized by males under varying conditions of thermal treatments (low: 24.5°C; high: 36°C), microbiome type (Axenic, Acetobacter tropicalis, Lactobacillus brevis, Control), and pesticide exposure (present and absent). Each colour represents a different microbiome treatment and two different panels correspond to presence/absence of pesticide treatment with two temperature treatments within each panel. Each circle represents the mean of all the replicates in that treatment combination with error bars corresponding to 95% confidence intervals.

Mean fecundity (±95% CI) of females mated to males exposed to different combinations of two thermal treatments (low: 24.5°C; high: 36°C), microbiome type (Axenic, Acetobacter tropicalis, Lactobacillus brevis, and Control), and pesticide exposure (No pesticide, Imidacloprid). Each circle represents the mean of replicates per treatment group. The left and right panels correspond to pesticide absence and presence, respectively, with temperature conditions shown on the x-axis. Colours represent different microbiome treatments.

Proportion of progenies sired by the focal males (2nd in order to mate with the female) under varying conditions of thermal treatments (low: 24.5°C; high: 36°C), microbiome type (Axenic, Acetobacter tropicalis, Lactobacillus brevis, Control), and pesticide exposure (present and absent). Each colour represents a different microbiome treatment and two different panels correspond to presence/absence of pesticide treatment with two temperature conditions (low/high) within each panel. Each circle represents the mean of all replicates in that treatment combination with error bars corresponding to 95% confidence intervals.

Bacterial abundance/colony forming units of different microbial treatment (Acetobacter tropicalis, Lactobacillus brevis, Control) in response to different conditions of thermal treatments (low: 24.5°C; high: 36°C), and pesticide exposure (present and absent). Each colour represents a different microbiome treatment and two different panels correspond to presence/absence of pesticide treatment with two temperature conditions (low/high) within each panel. Each circle represents the mean of all the replicates in that treatment combination with error bars corresponding to 95% confidence intervals.

Non-metric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) ordination (Bray-Curtis distance, k = 4, stress = 0.046) of microbial community composition across temperature and pesticide treatments. Each point represents one male, colored by temperature treatment (red = Low, blue = High) and shaped by pesticide exposure (circle = Absent, triangle = Present). Shaded convex hulls denote 95% confidence areas for each temperature × pesticide group. Arrows represent the direction and strength of species (Hellinger-transformed) most strongly correlated with the ordination space, as identified by envfit. Species abbreviations: Ao = Acetobacter orientalis, Ap = A. pasteuriensis, At = A. tropicalis, Lb = Lactobacillus brevis, Lp = L. plantarum.

Proportion of acetic acid bacteria in the five-species consortium in response to heat and pesticide stress. Each circle represents the mean of all replicates in that treatment combination with error bars corresponding to 95% confidence intervals.

Proportion of eggs hatched out of total number of eggs fertilized by male offspring produced by fathers under different conditions of thermal treatments (low: 24.5°C; high: 36°C), microbiome type (Axenic, Acetobacter tropicalis, Lactobacillus brevis, Control), and pesticide presence (present and absent). Each colour represents a different F0 microbiome treatment and two different panels correspond to presence/absence of F0 pesticide treatment with two F0 temperature conditions(low/high) within each panel. Each circle represents the mean of all the replicates in that treatment combination with error bars corresponding to 95% confidence intervals.

Proportion of hatched eggs out of total number of eggs laid by female offsprings produced by fathers under varying conditions of thermal treatments (low: 24.5°C; high: 36°C), microbiome type (Axenic, Acetobacter tropicalis, Lactobacillus brevis, Control), and pesticide presence (present and absent). Each colour represents a different F0 microbiome treatment and two different panels correspond to presence/absence of F0 pesticide treatment with two F0 temperature conditions(low/high) within each panel. Each circle represents the mean of all the replicates in that treatment combination with error bars corresponding to 95% confidence intervals.

Total number of fertilised eggs laid by females mated to male offsprings produced by fathers under varying conditions of thermal treatments (low: 24.5°C; high: 36°C), microbiome type (Axenic, Acetobacter tropicalis, Lactobacillus brevis, Control), and pesticide presence (present and absent). Each colour represents a different F0 microbiome treatment and two different panels correspond to presence/absence of F0 pesticide treatment with two F0 temperature conditions (low/high) within each panel. Each circle represents the mean of all the replicates in that treatment combination with error bars corresponding to 95% confidence intervals.

Total number of fertilised eggs laid by female offsprings produced by fathers under varying conditions of thermal treatments (low: 24.5°C; high: 36°C), microbiome type (Axenic, Acetobacter tropicalis, Lactobacillus brevis, Control), and pesticide presence (present and absent). Each colour represents a different F0 microbiome treatment and two different panels correspond to presence/absence of F0 pesticide treatment with two F0 temperature conditions (low/high) within each panel. Each circle represents the mean of all the replicates in that treatment combination with error bars corresponding to 95% confidence intervals.
